page.title: 04MITCHELDEAN CHURCH
page.content: Mitcheldean Church is a large and fine building, built largely of local stone. The nave has a high clerestory roof, and there is a south aisle and two north aisles. There is a chancel, south porch, and a tower with a tall spire at the western end of the south aisle. The oldest parts of the church are the nave, inner north aisle and the tower, which are 14th Century. The outer north aisle and the clerestory were added in 1460, and the chancel was added during restoration work in 1853. Notable features are the tall nave, the painted panels of the life of Christ, the font, the great marble reredos with its life size figures erected in 1911, and the modern east window of 1968. Recent work has included restoring the weather cock.
